title: How to adorn your plots

title: How to adorn your plots
text: number pre-defined colors come glitr package. objects starting grey belong family gray colors grey10k lightest grey90k darkest. Objects starting usaid_ official USAID colors starting wapo_ Washington Post inspired colors. siei_ colors largely style included posterity. color_denote objects can used filling captions, gridlines, plot text plot titles. family ofcolor_` objects follows colors recommended style guide. set colors probably interest SIEI recommended colors. may recall Data Visualization Style Guide, SI team created nine core colors: midnight_blue (#15478A) viking (#5BB5D5) slate (#8C8C91) electric_indigo (#3B5BBE) orchid_bloom (#E14BA1) sun_kissed (#F9C555) hunter (#419164) lavender_haze (#876EC4) tango (#F36428)   access full list discrete continuous palettes, see si_palettes list call color palette directly using name (si_palettes$color_name). OHA color names _d suffix (formerly singular), e.g. midnight_blue_d hunter_d, categorical palettes based suggested color pairs. OHA color names _c suffix (formerly plural), e.g lavender_haze_c sun_kissed_c, continuous palettes can applied continuous variables. OHA color names _t suffix, e.g. viking_t tango_t, tints base color broken roughly 20% increase lightness. attempt apply discrete palette continuous variable, color pairs recycled length vector attempting encode.    Finally, want create custom palette one color sets si_palettes list, can using si_rampr() function.
code: # Colors belonging to greys, usaid_, wapo_ or siei_. grep("(grey|siei_|wapo_|usaid_)", ls('package:glitr'), value = T) #>  [1] "grey10k"            "grey20k"            "grey30k"            #>  [4] "grey40k"            "grey50k"            "grey60k"            #>  [7] "grey70k"            "grey80k"            "grey90k"            #> [10] "light_grey"         "suva_grey"          "trolley_grey"       #> [13] "trolley_grey_light" "usaid_black"        "usaid_blue"         #> [16] "usaid_darkgrey"     "usaid_lightblue"    "usaid_lightgrey"    #> [19] "usaid_medblue"      "usaid_medgrey"      "usaid_red"          #> [22] "wapo_dblue"         "wapo_dmauve"        "wapo_dorange"       #> [25] "wapo_lblue"         "wapo_lgreen"        "wapo_lmauve"        #> [28] "wapo_lorange"       "wapo_lorange2"      "wapo_lpurple"       #> [31] "wapo_pushpop" # Any of these colors can be called by typing in the name of the color.  # The `show_col` function is from the `scales` package and is a handy way to preview a color.  show_col(hunter) show_col(c(electric_indigo, orchid_bloom, sun_kissed, hunter, lavender_haze, tango), borders = F, ncol = 6) # Returns the recommended paired colors with hunter as the base si_palettes$hunter_d %>% show_col(labels = F, borders = F, ncol = length(si_palettes$hunter_d)) # Returns an set of vector of color values that increase the amount of lightness/white si_palettes$hunter_t %>% show_col(labels = F, borders = F,  ncol = length(si_palettes$hunter_t)) # Returns an interpolated vector of color values around the base hunter color si_palettes$hunter_c %>% show_col(labels = F, borders = F,  ncol = length(si_palettes$hunter_c)) # si_rampr takes a palette name and the number of interpolated colors (n) you wish to return as arguments.  tango_c_pal <- si_rampr(pal_name = "tango_c", n = 25) tango_c_pal #>  [1] "#65331E" "#6F371F" "#793B20" "#833F22" "#8D4425" "#964828" "#A04D2B" #>  [8] "#A9532F" "#B25934" "#BA5F39" "#C2653E" "#CA6C44" "#D1734B" "#D87952" #> [15] "#DE815A" "#E48962" "#EB916B" "#EF9975" "#F4A17F" "#F7AA8A" "#FAB396" #> [22] "#FDBCA2" "#FDC5AF" "#FDCFBD" "#FDD9CB"  show_col(tango_c_pal, labels = F, borders = F)

title: How to adorn your plots
text: add colors graph, pass arguments ggplot2 call. work one sample data sets create bar graph positive testing results colored electric_indigo.  Another way use colors plots assign color values new column data frame. example, say like highlight two partners conducted greatest number tests. First, create ranking variable ranks partners total testing. assign set colors based rankings.  apply continuous OHA palette visualization, can use scale_fill_si() scale_color_si() function. example , create heat map, using geom_tile(), show testing targets vary across modality.  , graphic informative. Everything light shade lavender_haze_c. case? look distribution data, see skews heavily toward 0. Many targets appear lower end, outliers really mucking color encoding. can couple things make graphic informative. scale_fill_si() function takes ... argument, can pass transformation option plot, well define new set breaks.
code: # Munge the hts data down to testing yields for a given year   hts_bar <-     hts %>%     filter(period == "FY50",             period_type == "cumulative") %>%     group_by(indicator, prime_partner_name) %>%     summarise(total = sum(value, na.rm = TRUE),               .groups = "drop") %>%     pivot_wider(names_from = indicator,                  values_from = total,                 names_glue = "{tolower(indicator)}") %>%     mutate(positivity = (hts_tst_pos / hts_tst),            prime_order = fct_reorder(prime_partner_name, hts_tst)) %>%    arrange(prime_order)  # Define testing results to be grey30k and positive results to be viking  # Play close attention to where the fill is placed in the geom_col() call.  # If placed inside the aesthetics, you will need to apply scale_fill_identity() to get the colors to render.   p <- hts_bar %>%      ggplot(aes(y = prime_order)) +     geom_col(aes(x = hts_tst), fill = grey30k) +     geom_col(aes(x = hts_tst_pos), fill = midnight_blue) +     labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "HTS_TST_POS FILLED WITH MIDNIGHT BLUE COLOR",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings",          caption = "Source: glitr package `hts` dummy data")   p # Create a rank column, then assign colors based on threshold (<=2)  hts_bar_rnkd <- hts_bar %>%    mutate(hts_rank = dense_rank(desc(hts_tst)),           rnk_color = case_when(            hts_rank <= 2 ~ midnight_blue,             TRUE ~ viking            )          )   hts_bar_rnkd %>% filter(hts_rank < 7) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   prime_partner_name hts_tst hts_tst_pos positivity prime_order hts_rank #>   <chr>                <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> <fct>          <int> #> 1 Ursa Major           14360        1740     0.121  Ursa Major         6 #> 2 Capricornus          21920        2020     0.0922 Capricornus        5 #> 3 Corvus               24430        1240     0.0508 Corvus             4 #> 4 Eridanus             36620        1560     0.0426 Eridanus           3 #> 5 Libra                64580        2460     0.0381 Libra              2 #> 6 Sagittarius          66470        3870     0.0582 Sagittarius        1 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: rnk_color <chr>    # Assign colors to top two ranked prime partners and plot.  # Use the scale_fill_identity() to let ggplot2 know where fill is from.  hts_bar_rnkd %>%     ggplot(aes(y = prime_order, x = hts_tst, fill = rnk_color)) +    geom_col() +    scale_fill_identity() +       labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "HTS_TST FILLED BASED ON IDENTITY",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings",          caption = "Source: glitr package `hts` dummy data") hts_hm <- hts %>%    filter(period_type == "targets", period == "FY50") %>%    group_by(prime_partner_name) %>%    mutate(total_targets = sum(value, na.rm = T)) %>%    ungroup() %>%    mutate(partner_order = fct_reorder(prime_partner_name, total_targets))  hts_hm %>%    ggplot(aes(x = modality, y = partner_order, fill = value)) +    geom_tile(color = "white") +   scale_fill_si(palette = "lavender_haze_c", reverse = TRUE) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL,         title = "UNIMPRESSIVE HEAT MAP WITH HUNTER CONTINUOUS FILL",        subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings",        caption = "Source: glitr package `hts` dummy data") # Log transform data, clean up legend, apply semi-transparency (alpha) and label   hts_hm %>%      ggplot(aes(x = modality, y = partner_order, fill = value)) +      geom_tile(color = "white") +     scale_fill_si(palette = "lavender_haze_c", alpha = 0.85, trans = "log",                    breaks = c(1 * 10^(1:5)), reverse = TRUE,                   labels = comma,                   name = "Targets") +     labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "LOG-TRANSFORMED COLOR ENCODING",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings",          caption = "Source: glitr package `hts` dummy data"          ) +     geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(value > 10000, comma(value), NA_real_)),               size = 8/.pt, family = "Source Sans Pro", color = "white",               na.rm = TRUE) +     scale_x_discrete(guide = guide_axis(n.dodge = 2), position = "top") +   theme_minimal()

title: How to adorn your plots
text: order create visualizations appear belong family (Think Baldwin Brothers), glitr includes nine ggplot themes simplify plot core elements. base themes si_style(). can see differs default ggplot2 theme applying theme plot .  notice si_style strips background gray color converts grid lines light shade gray. plot oriented horizontally, can remove extra y gridlines using si_style_xgrid theme. si themes also come pre-formatted titles, subtitles, captions following style guild standards.
code: grep("(si_style)", ls('package:glitr'), value = T) #>  [1] "si_style"             "si_style_map"         "si_style_nolines"     #>  [4] "si_style_transparent" "si_style_void"        "si_style_xgrid"       #>  [7] "si_style_xline"       "si_style_xyline"      "si_style_ygrid"       #> [10] "si_style_yline" p + si_style() +   labs(subtitle = "si_style_() | Title, subtitle and caption formatted.") p +    si_style_xgrid() +    scale_x_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(caption = "Source: glitr package `hts` dummy data",        subtitle = "si_style_xgrid() | Title, subtitle and caption formatted.") +   coord_cartesian(expand = F) # Move names closer to y-axis

title: How to adorn your plots
text: summary graphic showing available SI themes.
code: # Create a list of all themes to loop over   theme_list <- list('si_style()' = si_style(),                       'si_style_xline()' = si_style_xline(),                       'si_style_xgrid()' = si_style_xgrid(),                      'si_style_xyline()' = si_style_xyline(),                       'si_style_yline()' = si_style_yline(),                       'si_style_ygrid()' = si_style_ygrid(),                       'si_style_nolines()' = si_style_nolines(),                       'si_style_void()' = si_style_void()                      )  # Custom plot function to incorporate themes   custom_plot <- function(x) {     p + {{x}}   }  # Make all the plots     plots <- map2(theme_list, names(theme_list),  ~custom_plot(.x) +                    labs(subtitle = paste(.y), title = NULL) +                   theme(axis.text = element_text(size = 12/.pt)))     # Create a sample map  hts_map <-  hts_geo %>%     ggplot() +     geom_sf(aes(fill = prime_partner_name)) +     si_style_map() +     scale_fill_si(palette = "siei", discrete = T) +    theme(legend.position = "none") +     labs(subtitle = 'si_style_map()')      reduce(plots, `+`) +      hts_map +     plot_annotation(subtitle = "A comparison of si_style() themes",                     theme = si_style()) +     plot_layout(ncol = 3)

title: Available Colors
text: USAID Graphics Standard Manual lays two colors found agency’s logo primary branding color palette, USAID Blue USAID Red. colors used “reinforce aid American people” provide limited range colors work data visualization. OHA developed offshoot colors visualization, expanding number categorical colors choose creating color-blind friendly palette (508 compliant). started primary USAID Blue used combination platforms (Adobe Color, Viz Palette, Coolors, Behance, chroma.js, Adobe Illustrator), identify modifying offshoot categorical palette. USAID Red dropped due high saturation often negative connotations associated use Western culture mean threat danger. , expanded identified colors full palette categorical continuous/sequential colors using tints. finally revisiting USAID Blue, dropping saturation roughly 20 percent reduce stark contrast used graphic elements visualization. addition color encoding visuals, also identified assortment grays used chart elements. application specific colors chart elements enhances visual’s look feel OHA product. Strategic use OHA palette allows consistent branding reduces time needed think color choices every visualization. said, colors used meaningfully thought given standard colors accentuate visual/message. doubt colors use, try creating visualization black white first. , add color specific elements one time data sufficiently encoded reinforce message. Outside visualization, default using USAID branding color palette prescribed typeface banners, text, text boxes. USAID colors available use graphs charts, however OHA palette specifically use data visualization products (charts, graphs, visuals etc.).

what: List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
title: List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
text: Sets color palettes collected SI team. Includes colors SIEI data visualization guide additional palettes. Colors stored named list. Use palette name position call colors. Color sets stored name first color. Calling si_palettes$viking_d return five color palette viking base. Calling si_palettes$viking_c return interpolated ramp 10 colors viking Calling si_palettes$viking_t return viking four tints 80%, 60%, 40%, 20%. See SIEI data visualization guide additional details.

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
text: function adorns ggplot convert SI style plot. default font Source Sans Pro

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
code: si_style(   font_title,   font_subtitle,   font_plot,   font_caption,   facet_space = 2,   text_scale = 1,   FO = FALSE,   ... )

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
text: font_title font family titles, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_subtitle font family subtitles, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_plot font family plot space, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_caption font family captions, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial facet_space controls far apart facets text_scale scalar grow/shrink text defined within FO make everything black (, knows) ... pass parameters theme already defined within

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(systemfonts) library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() + si_style()   } # }

title: Create Standard SI Map — si_style_map
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  library(systemfonts) library(tidyverse) library(glitr) library(gisr) library(sf)  sfdf <- gisr::get_admin1("Nigeria") %>%  select(name) %>%  mutate(value = runif(nrow(.), 0, 1))  ggplot() +    geom_sf(data = sfdf,            aes(fill = value),            color = grey10k,            size = .1) +    scale_fill_si(palette = "genoas",                  discrete = FALSE,                  limits = c(0, 1),                  labels = scales::percent) +    labs(title = "NIGERIA - % OF PLHIV BY STATE",         subtitle = "States from XYZ Region are the most hit by HIV/AIDS",         caption = base::paste0("Produced by OHA/SIEI/SI, ON ", base::Sys.Date())) +   si_style_map() +   si_legend_fill() } # }

title: glitr 0.2
text: Add si_style_transparent theme transparent visuals [2020-07-17] Update vignette new set available OHA colors site [2024-07-17] Set default fill.color scale_*_si slate [2024-07-16] Add si_palette, changing old version “classic” adding full range tints continuous ramps [2024-06-11] Modify colors Hemsworth palette based feedback - midnight_blue, slate, lavender_haze [2024-06-06] Add hw_slate extend Hemsworth palette & add hemsworth option si_palettes [2024-02-11] Change instructions install rOpenSci [2024-01-04] Update font vignette describe changing graphic options [2023-12-12] Add Hemsworth palette (hw_*) testing [2023-12-11] Add new Patone 2024 color year [2023-12-07] Resolve bug extrafonts warning [2023-11-15] Flag extrafonts loaded suggest removal restart [2023-10-17] Update vignettes examples systemfonts [2023-10-27] Implement site build via GitHub Action [2023-10-27] Replace use extrafont systemfonts work efficiently across platforms obviated need stick old version Rttf2pt1 [2023-10-23] Change default font look use either Source Sans 3 (preferred) Source Sans Pro [2023-09-07]

title: glitr 0.1.1
